I bought this camera mainly for my parents. Well, selected, actually--they paid for it :) There's already an SLR in the house, so the reasoning behind buying this camera was that there should be a camera in the family that's light and compact enough to be carried around easily everywhere. Yes, the price is well into the entry-level SLR territory, and SLRs do seem more attractive for a lot of reasons, some valid, some not. However, having spent A LOT of time shooting DSLRs, I can tell you that their weight and bulk quickly gets annoying. At times, it'll simply feel silly to be toting a huge camera bag, say, to small events, or in a restaurant. On such occasions, you'll want a camera that can take good pictures (or videos) but also isn't an awkward burden to carry.But enough ranting and on to the camera.The P7800 is the at the very top of the Coolpix P-series, which stands for Performance, which means that this is at the very high-end of Nikon's non-DSLR, feature- and performance-wise. As I see it, it's aimed at people who'd like more control over technical parameters, as in SLRs, and also comparable image quality, but in a compact form.The main, outstanding features (ie. the specifications that actually matter, but don't get as much mention) are:1) Lens equivalent focal length 28-200mm (7x zoom) with VR (vibration reduction) : What this means is that you can comfortably take wide-angle shots like landscapes, family portraits, etc, and also zoom in to reasonably distant subjects. No, you'll never need the 20x, 30x & 60x that you see in a lot of similar models. That usually compromises on other aspects of lens quality. If you had to be clicking snow leopards for Nat Geo, you wouldn't be reading this review.2) Large lens aperture f/2-4 : These numbers are very good for this segment of camera, and they matter A LOT. This translates to much better results in low-light. That means not just night-time, but most indoors shots. Even a regular phone camera can yield impressive image-quality in bright daylight; true quality shows up only in poor lighting which is where a lot of photos get easily blurred or come out grainy.3) Large sensor 1/1.7 inches : Again, this is very good. This also translates to less grainy pictures in poor light and overall better image sharpness & quality. Megapixels mean nothing, sensor size is everything.4) Professional-oriented dials/buttons & shooting modes: Depends on personal preferences. If you're familiar with the technicalities and want more control, the dedicated controls mean not having to dive into menus every time. If you just want to point and shoot, just set it on full-auto and ignore all those other dials, as my parents do. The auto mode nowadays is smart enough so you never have to select those scene-specific modes like 'beach', 'landscape', 'night-portrait', etc.5) Electronic viewfinder - the little window that you peek through. Very useful when, on a very bright day, the glare makes it hard to see the image on the screen. Also, when you're running low on battery. The screen, btw, is very good, and has an anti-glare coating, but it's still good to have the EVF.6) Popup flash - there's a separate button to make it pop out; you need to push it back in manually. This is good because you can choose when to activate the flash easily, rather than have the camera pop it up when you son't need it, or having to change flash settings in a menu.7) Flip out screen: not a must, but good to have sometimes, say, if you're shooting a flower on the ground and you don't want to have to lie down for it. You can also turn and close it to protect the screen.On the whole, image and video quality on this has been excellent. It feels nice & comfortable in the hand. There are a couple of issues.1) The camera case supplied with it is terrible. It's clearly not designed for this model. You have to literally push and squeeze it into the case till it's bulging.2) The lens cap doesn't have a hole for a loop, so it can't be secured to the camera. Some jugaad required.On the whole, I'd say that the number of physical controls and menu options on this camera can seem pretty intimidating at first to someone who isn't too tech-savvy, specially compared to cameras that sacrifice the controllability for a sleek, minimalistic design. So it's likely that many people will find it a bit chunky or boxy or unnecessarily complex. However, those sleeker cameras also have lower specs in several vital areas simply because of the bussiness-sense of clubbing point-and-shoot level specs with point-and-shoot design. And you can always just ignore all those controls and shoot in full-auto mode, which is excellent, and you'd still be getting the advantage of the better lens, sensor, processing chip and sturdy metallic body of this camera.P.S.- Another great and much cheaper alternative to this model is the Nikon Coolpix P340. Well worth consideration.
